flow.descriptionCdata:
ae3aee0a-76f9-40a9-80d3-ce5456f409da.11815d0c-60f7-4581-b660-7b4c329ac968.description=
Removes a file/folder

Input Parameters\:
source - full path to file or directory

Responses\:
success - file/directory removed successfully
failure - unable to remove file/directory
ae3aee0a-76f9-40a9-80d3-ce5456f409da.2df9a433-3fb4-4edb-adc6-b78e0f0e5e71.description=
Adds two numbers together

Inputs\:
value1 - The first value.
value2 - The second value.

Returns\:
The sum of the two numbers.

Responses\:
success - The operation completed successfully.
failure - Something went wrong.
ae3aee0a-76f9-40a9-80d3-ce5456f409da.7e54add7-bacc-4870-919b-07760731d15e.description=
This operation reads the content of a file. The operation can be used to read the entire file content in one step or to iterate the file line by line.

Inputs\:
    source - The full path and filename of the file to be read. A UNC path can be supported as the source file path.
    filter - The string to filter on (leave blank for no filter). If this filter is not blank, all rows that contain the filter string will be returned. If no match is found, no lines will be returned.
    iterate - Determines whether the content of the file should be iterated or not. If set to "true", the content of the file will be iterated row by row and for each subsequent call, the next row will be returned. If set to "false", the content of the file will not be iterated and only the number of lines that matched the "filter" will be returned.
Valid values\: true, false
    delimiter – If specified, the entire content of the file  will be read, the specified value will be used as a delimiter between the rows and  the resulting content will be returned. If left blank, the next row will be returned for each subsequent call. 
    eofReset - If set to true, after the No More response has been returned once, the operation will restart reading the file from the beginning on the next call.
Valid values\: true, false
    characterSet - The character set of the file to read from. For invalid or empty input value the default encoding will be used. 
Valid values\: UTF-8, UTF-16 and UTF-32 
Default value\: UTF-8

Results\:
    returnCode - This is the primary output. It is 0 if the operation completed successfully  (or if more rows are available when iterate is set to true), 1 if no more items (if iterate is set to true) and -1 in case of failure. 
    count - The number of lines that matched the filter, or if no filter specified, the total lines read (if iterate is false, or delimiter is not null). Otherwise, it returns the number of rows available for retrieval from the source file.
    returnResult - Each row by turn (if iterate is true and delimiter is blank) or all rows separated by the delimiter (if iterate is true and delimiter is not blank).
    exception - An exception message if the operation fails.

Responses\:
    success - The operation successfully read the file (if iterate is true, more rows are available).
    no more items - No more items are available for retrieval (if iterate is set to true).
    failure - The operation failed to read the file.

Notes\:
1. The "filter" and "eofReset" fields are taken into consideration only if iterate is set to true. Otherwise, they have no impact on the result.
2. Note that the "filter" match is not performed based on a regular expression, although the filter field may contain one. The operation only checks for each row if it contains the string given as filter. 
3. If i"terate" is set to "true" and "delimiter" is not null, the entire file may or may not still be fully read at once, depending on size. 
4. If "iterate" is set to "true", then all matching lines are pushed into the Session and then, subsequent calls to the operation, result in the next line being returned.
5. If the value provided in the "delimiter" field is not null, the entire file will be read once and returned regardless of the value of the "iterate" field.

Examples\:
    The following examples are used to illustrate the behavior of the operation for three specific use cases. For these examples, the operation will use as the input source a file called "example.txt", with the absolute path "C\:\Program Files\example.txt" and the following content\:
        "line1
         line2
         line3
         line4"
1. This is a valid inputs example for reading the content of a file, when the "iterate" input field is set to "true" and the "delimiter" input field is not left blank\:
        source\: C\:\Program Files\example.txt
        filter\:
        iterate\: true
        delimiter\: ,
        eofReset\: false
        characterSet\: UTF-8
    In this case, the "returnResult" output field of the operation will have the following value\: line1,line2,line3,line4
2. This is a valid inputs example for reading the content of a file, when the "iterate" input field is set to "true" and the delimiter input field is left blank\:
        source\: C\:\Program Files\example.txt
        filter\:
        iterate\: true
        delimiter\:
        eofReset\: false
        characterSet\: UTF-8
    In this case, the file will be iterated row by row in four subsequent calls. At each call, the "returnResult" output field of the operation will contain the value of one line from the file, in the same order as they are found in the source file (i.e. line1, line2, lin3, line4). 
3. This is a valid inputs example for reading the content of a file, when the "iterate" input field is set to "false" and the "delimiter" input field is left blank\:       
        source\: C\:\Program Files\example.txt
        filter\:
        iterate\: false
        delimiter\:
        eofReset\: false
        characterSet\: UTF-8
    In this case, the "returnResult" output field of the operation will be blank and the count output field will contain the value 4 (representing the number of lines in the file).
ae3aee0a-76f9-40a9-80d3-ce5456f409da.84b22bc3-5917-4287-8476-b66cb46415ea.description=
Checks if a number or word is greater than another number or word. Word comparison is case-sensitive in alphabetical order.

Inputs\:
value1 - The first value.
value2 - The second value.

Returns\:
value1 > value2

Responses\:
success - The boolean operation was evaluated to true.
failure - Something went wrong or the boolean operation returned false.
ae3aee0a-76f9-40a9-80d3-ce5456f409da.93c36b58-bbb8-4f1a-b0bb-b077c513fdfc.description=
This operation reads the content of a file. The operation can be used to read the entire file content in one step or to iterate the file line by line.

Inputs\:
    source - The full path and filename of the file to be read. A UNC path can be supported as the source file path.
    filter - The string to filter on (leave blank for no filter). If this filter is not blank, all rows that contain the filter string will be returned. If no match is found, no lines will be returned.
    iterate - Determines whether the content of the file should be iterated or not. If set to "true", the content of the file will be iterated row by row and for each subsequent call, the next row will be returned. If set to "false", the content of the file will not be iterated and only the number of lines that matched the "filter" will be returned.
Valid values\: true, false
    delimiter – If specified, the entire content of the file  will be read, the specified value will be used as a delimiter between the rows and  the resulting content will be returned. If left blank, the next row will be returned for each subsequent call. 
    eofReset - If set to true, after the No More response has been returned once, the operation will restart reading the file from the beginning on the next call.
Valid values\: true, false
    characterSet - The character set of the file to read from. For invalid or empty input value the default encoding will be used. 
Valid values\: UTF-8, UTF-16 and UTF-32 
Default value\: UTF-8

Results\:
    returnCode - This is the primary output. It is 0 if the operation completed successfully  (or if more rows are available when iterate is set to true), 1 if no more items (if iterate is set to true) and -1 in case of failure. 
    count - The number of lines that matched the filter, or if no filter specified, the total lines read (if iterate is false, or delimiter is not null). Otherwise, it returns the number of rows available for retrieval from the source file.
    returnResult - Each row by turn (if iterate is true and delimiter is blank) or all rows separated by the delimiter (if iterate is true and delimiter is not blank).
    exception - An exception message if the operation fails.

Responses\:
    success - The operation successfully read the file (if iterate is true, more rows are available).
    no more items - No more items are available for retrieval (if iterate is set to true).
    failure - The operation failed to read the file.

Notes\:
1. The "filter" and "eofReset" fields are taken into consideration only if iterate is set to true. Otherwise, they have no impact on the result.
2. Note that the "filter" match is not performed based on a regular expression, although the filter field may contain one. The operation only checks for each row if it contains the string given as filter. 
3. If i"terate" is set to "true" and "delimiter" is not null, the entire file may or may not still be fully read at once, depending on size. 
4. If "iterate" is set to "true", then all matching lines are pushed into the Session and then, subsequent calls to the operation, result in the next line being returned.
5. If the value provided in the "delimiter" field is not null, the entire file will be read once and returned regardless of the value of the "iterate" field.

Examples\:
    The following examples are used to illustrate the behavior of the operation for three specific use cases. For these examples, the operation will use as the input source a file called "example.txt", with the absolute path "C\:\Program Files\example.txt" and the following content\:
        "line1
         line2
         line3
         line4"
1. This is a valid inputs example for reading the content of a file, when the "iterate" input field is set to "true" and the "delimiter" input field is not left blank\:
        source\: C\:\Program Files\example.txt
        filter\:
        iterate\: true
        delimiter\: ,
        eofReset\: false
        characterSet\: UTF-8
    In this case, the "returnResult" output field of the operation will have the following value\: line1,line2,line3,line4
2. This is a valid inputs example for reading the content of a file, when the "iterate" input field is set to "true" and the delimiter input field is left blank\:
        source\: C\:\Program Files\example.txt
        filter\:
        iterate\: true
        delimiter\:
        eofReset\: false
        characterSet\: UTF-8
    In this case, the file will be iterated row by row in four subsequent calls. At each call, the "returnResult" output field of the operation will contain the value of one line from the file, in the same order as they are found in the source file (i.e. line1, line2, lin3, line4). 
3. This is a valid inputs example for reading the content of a file, when the "iterate" input field is set to "false" and the "delimiter" input field is left blank\:       
        source\: C\:\Program Files\example.txt
        filter\:
        iterate\: false
        delimiter\:
        eofReset\: false
        characterSet\: UTF-8
    In this case, the "returnResult" output field of the operation will be blank and the count output field will contain the value 4 (representing the number of lines in the file).
ae3aee0a-76f9-40a9-80d3-ce5456f409da.c3946de6-9f2b-4ff7-8502-0e980df4c023.description=
This operation writes the data from "contents" input to the requested file. The operation can be used to overwrite existing content of the file, append extra lines to it or even create a new file.

Inputs\:
    source -  Full path to file. If the file does not exist it is created first.
    contents - The content that should be written to the file. This input field can contain more lines, separated by a delimiter. If it contains the new line character (\n or \r\n), but this is not the delimiter, this character will be escaped and written to file.  
Example\: "This is line no. 01\nThis is line no. 2\n" where \n is the delimiter.
    delimiter - Specifies the newline delimiter that is used to split the "contents" input field into separate lines that will be further written to the given file.
Examples\: \n, \r\n, etc
    characterSet - The character encoding used to write to the file. 
Default\: UTF-8. 
Valid values\: windows-1252, UTF-16, UTF-16BE,  ISO-8859-1, US-ASCII, Shift_JIS etc.
    overwrite - Specifies whether to overwrite the file or append to it. 
Default\: true. 
Valid values\: true, false or the empty string. If this is left empty, the file will be overwritten.

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. It contains the "success" confirmation message if the operation successfully completes, or an exception message otherwise.
    returnCode - It has the value 0 if the operation successfully completes and 1 otherwise.
    exception - This contains an exception message if the operation fails.

Responses\:
    success - File/directory was written successfully.
    failure - Unable to write to file/directory, empty contents or source.

Examples\:
1. This is a valid input example for using this operation on Windows\:
    source\: C\:\Program Files\example.txt
    contents\: line1,line2,line3
    delimiter\: ,

2. This is a valid input example for using this operation on Linux\:
    source\: /root/example.txt
    contents\: line1,line2,line3
    delimiter\: ,
ae3aee0a-76f9-40a9-80d3-ce5456f409da.description=
Creare un flusso che legga in parallelo i 2 file.txt generati nell’ Esercizio 9.
Generare 2 valori, uno contenente la somma dei numeri pari, uno con la somma dei numeri dispari.
Se la somma di questi 2 valori è maggiore di 10, scrivere in un nuovo file.txt il seguente testo\: “La
somma dei numeri è\: VAR_SOMMA” ed andare in SUCCESS.
Se la somma è minore di 10, cancellare i 2 file.txt ed andare in FAILURE.
flow.name: 10-Somma Parellelo Flow
